org.obrel.core

Class RelatedObject

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.obrel.core.RelatedObject
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Relatable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AbstractFunction, JsonObject, JsonRelatedObject, Params, RelationSpace, RelationType, SerializableRelatedObject

    public class RelatedObject
extends java.lang.Object
implements Relatable
    The base class for all relation-enabled objects. It can be used as a base class but it is not abstract so that relations may also be added directly to instances of this class.

    If a subclass needs to intercept the relation handling of this class completely it should override all public non-final methods with the exception of the method toString() and the addition of the protected method deleteRelation(Relation).

      • get

        public <T> T get(RelationType<T> rType)
        Returns the resolved value of the relation that matches a certain relation type. If that relation does not exist already but the type implements the method RelationType.initialValue(Relatable) which returns a value that is not NULL a new relation with that target value will be created and it's resolved value returned. Otherwise the result of RelationType.defaultValue(Relatable) will be returned (which is NULL by default).

        The initial and default value mechanisms imply that this method cannot be used to check the existence of relations in an object. If a type provides an initial value relations will be created automatically when queried through this method. If it returns a default value the relation doesn't exist at all although a value is available. Therefore, to check for relations the method Relatable.hasRelation(RelationType) must be invoked instead. This will also avoid the automatic creation of the relations that are queried. In addition, other relation query methods like Relatable.getAll(Predicate) and Relatable.getRelation(RelationType) will ignore initial and default values.

        Specified by:
        get in interface Relatable
        Parameters:
        rType - The relation type to return the target of
        Returns:
        The resolved target object or NULL if no relation with the given type exists

      • getRelations

        public java.util.List<Relation<?>> getRelations(Predicate<? super Relation<?>> rFilter)
        Description copied from interface: Relatable
        Returns a list of all public relations that match a certain filter. The order in which the relations appear in the collection will be the same on multiple invocations of this method. The returned list can be freely modified by the caller.
        Specified by:
        getRelations in interface Relatable
        Parameters:
        rFilter - The relation filter or NULL for all relations
        Returns:
        A list containing the matching relations (may be empty but will never be NULL)
        See Also:
        Relatable.getRelations(Predicate)

      • relationsEqual

        public final boolean relationsEqual(RelatedObject rOther)
        Compares this instance's relations for equality with another related object. This method should be invoked by subclasses that implement the Object.equals(Object) and Object.hashCode() methods. From the latter subclasses should also invoke relationsHashCode() for a consistent implementation of these methods.
        Parameters:
        rOther - The other object to compare this instance's relations with
        Returns:
        TRUE if the relations of this instance equal that of the other object

        sSeparator - The separator between relations
        nIndent - The indentation level (zero for the first, -1 for no indentation)

      • set

        public final <T,I> Relation<T> set(RelationType<T> rType,
                                   Function<I,T> fTargetResolver,
                                   I rIntermediateTarget)
        Creates a relation that initially stores the target value in an intermediate format. When the relation target is queried it will be created by applying a conversion function to the intermediate value. This allows to lazily initialize relations only when they are really needed.

        If a relation with the given type exists already this method will throw an exception to prevent the inadvertent overriding of relations. If the caller explicitly wants to replace an existing relation it must delete the previous relation before invoking this method.

        The serialized format of an intermediate relation depends on the intermediate target value and the conversion function. If both are serializable they will be serialized directly. If one of them is not serializable the intermediate target value will be converted to the final target format before which will then be serialized.

        This method is intended to be used by frameworks that need to prevent the early resolving of relations. A possible application would be a persistence framework that wants to perform lazy loading of child objects.

        Specified by:
        set in interface Relatable
        Parameters:
        rType - The relation type
        fTargetResolver - The function that must be applied to the intermediate target value to resolve the final target value
        rIntermediateTarget - The intermediate target value (must not be NULL)
        Returns:
        The new intermediate relation

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a string representation of this instance. The returned string will be composed of the simple class name followed by a comma-separated list of all relations in brackets. In this list all non-private relations will be formatted as <TYPE>=<TARGET>.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        See Also:
        Object.toString()

      • transform

        public <T,D> TransformedRelation<T,D> transform(RelationType<T> rType,
                                                InvertibleFunction<T,D> fTransformation)
        Creates a relation that stores the target value in a transformed format. If a new target value is set it will be converted to the transformed format by applying a transformation function. If the target is queried from the relation it will be created from the transformed value by inverting the transformation. Therefore the function argument must implement the InvertibleFunction interface.

        If a relation with the given type exists already it will be replaced with the transformed relation and it's current target value will be transformed automatically. If no such relation exists the transformation will be created with the initial value of the relation type.

        If a transformed relation shall be serializable both it's transformed target value and the transformation function must be serializable too. Otherwise an exception will occur when an attempt is made to serialize the relation.

        This method is intended to be used by frameworks that want to provide a way to store relations in a specific format. A possible application would be a framework that encrypts relations.

        Specified by:
        transform in interface Relatable
        Parameters:
        rType - The relation type
        fTransformation - The transformation to apply to target values
        Returns:
        The new transformed relation

                                           Relation<T> rRelation,
                                           T rUpdateValue)
        A package-internal method that notifies all registered relation listeners of a certain relation event.
        Parameters:

        rRelation - The relation that is affected by the event
        rUpdateValue - The update value in case of a relation update

      • readRelations

        protected final void readRelations(java.io.ObjectInputStream rIn)
                            throws java.io.IOException,
                                   java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        Helper method for serializable subclasses to read the relations of this instance from the given input stream in the format that has been written by the method writeRelations(ObjectOutputStream).
        Parameters:
        rIn - The object input stream to read from
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If reading a relation fails
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - If a relation class is not available

      • relationsHashCode

        protected final int relationsHashCode()
        Calculates the hash code of this instance's relations. This method should be invoked by subclasses that implement the Object.hashCode() and Object.equals(Object) methods. From the latter subclasses should also invoke relationsEqual(RelatedObject) for a consistent implementation of these methods.
        Returns:
        The hash code of this instance's relations

      • writeRelations

        protected final void writeRelations(java.io.ObjectOutputStream rOut)
                             throws java.io.IOException
        Helper method for serializable subclasses to write the relations of this instance to the given output stream. It will first write the count of the relations and then all non-transient relations by directly serializing them to the stream.
        Parameters:
        rOut - The output stream to write the relations to
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If writing a relation fails
